ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned how to work with a team to create a model and recommendations for our client, WomanKind Kenya. I also learned about climate change, climate adaptation, and gender in Garissa, Kenya.
Strong personal research skills, literature review strategies, analytical skills, communication skills, and teambuilding
I was able to develop practical skills of conducting qualitative research and how to navigate a different culture

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: You do learn a lot doing a project like this, but it's a bit of a trial by fire. At certain points, it felt like we got thrown into the deep end and had to learn to swim very quickly, learning how to work as a team, work with our client, and understand the issues and the culture in a very short space of time and all virtually.  We were lucky in that our advisor was amazing, but our client was not very helpful. They took a really long time to send us information that was often vague or incomplete and didn't seem engaged in the project they asked us to do. I think the capstone project could be improved if we started the year with a basic workshop on doing the capstone in general and working with a client where previous seniors could give advice and answer questions. It would also have been good if the judges and Jackson representatives had given us written feedback on our final presentation and report.

This course was one of the most rewarding and fun courses I've taken at Yale thanks to Fauziya, who's guidance was extremely helpful. The content matter was engaging given our personal investment in the task, and knowing that our deliverable would have an impact made the work more meaningful.
strength is that it gets you accustomed to working with a group as well as working for an organization

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Virtual learning was a pretty significant challenge in this capstone. Because we weren't allowed to go to Garissa, it was very hard to get an idea of what the situation was on the ground and make helpful recommendations. We also had several issues with tech and time zones when meeting with our advisor or interviewees.

Fauziya helped facilitate the move online flawlessly - she helped arranged virtual speakers for us, a virtual tour of Garissa even though we could not go in person, and helped keep us on track with self managed work via timelines.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Given that you have to do it to graduate, I would just say 1) pick an advisor with whom you really want to work and 2) a topic that you really want to learn about because you will be spending a lot of time on this project and both of those things make a big difference to your experience.
Absolutely - it has been my favorite part of the Global major.
